Prescribed medication.0: Lansoprazole for Reflux with history of Gout

What you want to be able to do?.0: I liked to run but too unfit to do that now. I want a realistic entry into getting fitter where I build up the intensity to match my capability. I dont enjoy squats as they make my legs hurt but recognise I may need to do them.

How you want to look?.0: Lose the 18kg of weight I have put on since 2019 and get to a target weight of 82kg

How you want to feel?.0: Have more energy and know my health is improving

recommendations: Main aim is improving BS control/improve insulin sensitivity and CHD risk profile (↑ aerobic CV, ↓Body fat/BMI if applicable, ↑lifestyle change).
Functional movements should take preference – mimic movement patterns.
Use functional fitness tests and health tests, such as 6MWT, sit to stand, peak flow, balance testing, co-ordination testing.
Clients should be able to test own BS levels – ideally pre and post exercise.
New clients should avoid exercising alone due to higher risk of hypo.
Prolonged warm-up and cool-down (15minutes) – gradual ROM and intensity increases to dilate coronary arteries thus aiding blood flow.
Consider time of day – avoid 3 hours prior to sleep due to nocturnal hypoglycaemia unless increasing carbohydrate intake.
contraindications: Consider time of day – avoid 3 hours prior to sleep due to nocturnal hypoglycaemia unless increasing carbohydrate intake.
Avoid high impacts/jarring - ↑risks, such as retinopathy and neuropathy.
Avoid exercising during peak insulin activity and injection site areas as it speeds up medications action (abdominal site best rather than exercising limbs).
VM, breathe holding and over-gripping equipment – potentially ↑BP.

Warning signs (hypo or hyper) – extreme fatigue, irritable, nausea, intermittent claudication, frequent urination, extreme thirst/hunger, blurry vision/disorientated - anything different to a ‘normal’ response.

recommendations: Main aim is improving/maintaining aerobic capacity (↑ aerobic CV, ↑muscle strength/lifestyle change, ↑ADL`s).
Functional movements should take preference – mimic movement patterns where possible to aid ADLs.
Use functional fitness tests and health tests such as 6MWT, sit to stand, peak flow, balance testing, co-ordination testing.
Ensure medication is available throughout sessions – SABs.
Prolonged warm-up and cool-down (15 minutes) – gradual ROM and intensity increases aiding bronchial dilation – EIA SABs prior to exercise.
contraindications: Consider temperature and time of day/environmental triggers (EIA).
Warning signs – excessive coughing, excessive SOB, lower exercise tolerance – no exercise during exacerbation periods or unstable diagnosis.
Ensuring clients with asthma have written personal asthma plans.
To reduce the risk of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, clients with asthma may need to take their reliever bronchodilator medication 15 minutes before exercise (upon agreement with GP).
Wearing a scarf to cover the mouth and nose during cold weather can also help prevent EIA .
The client should also be encouraged to use the breathing techniques that are taught as part of their treatment.
Make sure you know what to do in the event of an asthma attack.

diet.Diet:Do's: Eat a variety of fruits and vegetables, focusing on dark-colored produce like spinach, kale, and berries, which are rich in antioxidants.
diet.Diet:Don't: Limit your intake of processed and packaged foods, sugary drinks, and saturated fats found in foods like butter, lard, and partially hydrogenated oils.

Start Slowly.Recommendations: When starting a new exercise routine, begin with shorter sessions (20-30 minutes) and gradually increase duration and intensity as your body adapts.

Warm Up and Cool Down.Recommendations: Always include a 5-10 minute warm-up (light cardio, stretching) before your workout and a 5-10 minute cool-down (static stretching) afterwards to prevent injuries and improve recovery.

Listen to Your Body.Recommendations: Rest when needed, and avoid pushing through pain or discomfort. If you experience any severe pain or injury, stop immediately and consult a medical professional.

Recommendations.Hydration: Drink at least 8-10 glasses of water per day to maintain proper hydration levels, especially for individuals with high activity levels or living in hot climates.
Recommendations.Supplements and Minerals: Consult with your healthcare provider to determine necessary supplements and minerals tailored to your specific needs, such as calcium for bone health or vitamin D for immune function.
Recommendations.Regular Monitoring: Regularly monitor your health status, tracking vital signs, and discussing any concerns or changes with your healthcare provider.

Potential Risk Factors.Recommendation: Limit daily alcohol consumption to no more than one drink for women and two drinks for men, and avoid binge drinking altogether.
Quit smoking immediately to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease, lung cancer, and other smoking-related health issues.

Condition-Specific Considerations.Diabetes: Regularly monitor blood sugar levels and work closely with your healthcare provider to manage diabetes through medication, lifestyle modifications, and regular check-ups.
Condition-Specific Considerations.Hypertension: Monitor blood pressure regularly and follow your healthcare provider's recommendations for medication and lifestyle changes to manage hypertension.

General Tips.Description: Aim for 7-8 hours of sleep per night to help regulate stress, repair tissues, and maintain overall health.
Engage in stress-reducing activities, such as meditation, deep breathing, or yoga, to help manage stress and maintain mental well-being.
